extraction_metadata.notes: This appears to be a confession record only - no witness testimony is included in this document. The trial outcome is unknown from this extract. The document notes she was 'fugitive from St Dié for that reason' suggesting prior accusations there. Economic hardship is evident: husband worked in mines and gave her nothing; she sold eggs for income (healing services). She practiced healing (cured le Gros Claude by having him buy and eat her eggs). Temporal note: seduction occurred 14-15 years before 1561 (c.1546-1547); hailstorm 12-13 years before (c.1548-1549). Possible name variants: Blaise Laneçon vs Blaise Lanceon vs Colin Lanceon - may be same family or transcription variants. Thursday evening sabbats are notable timing detail.
